title: AI discovery pipeline: automate Haiku discovery → Opus validation → review queue
description:
Build the automated AI resource discovery pipeline that runs daily.

## Pipeline Stages

### Stage 1: Discovery (Haiku - high volume, cheap)
- Run discovery prompts from .prompts/discover-*.md
- Target specific regions/categories
- Output: ResourceCandidate JSON list
- High volume, accept some false positives

### Stage 2: Validation (Opus - thorough, accurate)  
- Run .prompts/validate-resource.md on each candidate
- Check: links work, phone valid, org exists
- Run .prompts/dedupe-check.md against existing DB
- Output: validated candidates with confidence scores

### Stage 3: Review Queue
- High confidence (>0.9): auto-approve to DB
- Medium confidence (0.7-0.9): add to review queue
- Low confidence (<0.7): discard with log

## Key Files
- .prompts/ - Discovery and validation prompts (already exist)
- backend/scripts/import_discoveries.py - Manual import (reference)
- backend/app/services/discovery.py - Discovery service
- backend/jobs/scheduler.py - APScheduler for daily runs
- backend/app/api/v1/admin.py - Review queue endpoints

- Uses Haiku for discovery, Opus for validation
- Auto-approves high-confidence resources
- Review queue for medium-confidence
- Admin can approve/reject from queue

title: Design no-PII eligibility wizard + per-location requirements for local resources
description: Create a concrete design/spec for a guided narrowing experience that helps users find *local* veteran resources without storing PII. Focus on housing (SSVF/senior housing) for the DC/MD/VA region, with extensibility to other categories (food distributions, benefits consults). The goal is to move beyond national VA.gov pages by modeling per-location eligibility, intake steps, and verification metadata.
design:
## Problem
Most resources discovered so far are national VA.gov pages. Local resources (SSVF providers, senior housing, food distributions, benefits consults) have location-specific eligibility and intake constraints. Users—especially seniors and less tech-savvy vets—need step-by-step narrowing and clear next actions, but we must not store PII.

## Goals
- Guided eligibility narrowing with zero PII storage
- Per-location modeling for programs with differing rules by provider/location
- Explainable results (“why this matches”) and actionable intake steps
- Verification metadata + low-friction correction reporting
- Initial focus: DC/MD/VA housing ecosystem (SSVF + senior housing), extensible later

## Non-goals
- No accounts
- No storage of names, addresses, phone numbers, SSNs, DOBs
- No scheduling/booking system
- No eligibility determination guarantees (only guidance)

## Proposed UX
### 1) Entry points
- Existing State selector map → leads to a local search context
- Add an "Eligibility Wizard" panel (optional) at top of search/discover/hub pages

### 2) Eligibility Wizard (anonymous)
Inputs should be coarse/bucketed:
- State + optional ZIP (ZIP used only to compute distance client-side; never stored server-side)
- Household size (1, 2, 3, 4, 5+)
- Gross monthly income (bucketed ranges, or exact number processed client-side)
- Age bracket (<55, 55–61, 62+, 65+)
- Disability (yes/no/prefer not to say)
- Housing status (homeless / at-risk / stably housed)
- Served on active duty at least once (yes/no)
- Discharge status (unknown/other-than-dishonorable/dishonorable)
- Counties/cities served (derived from ZIP or chosen)

### 3) Result presentation
- Each resource shows:
  - Match reasons chips (e.g., “62+”, “Serves Fairfax County”, “Income under 50% AMI”)
  - Clear intake CTA (Call, Website, Directions)
  - "What to bring" checklist
  - Last verified date + verification source
  - Report update (no identity required)

### 4) Privacy approach
- Store wizard inputs in URL query params and/or client localStorage only
- Backend receives filters only for the current request; no persistence/logging of raw inputs
- Avoid analytics logging query strings (future)

## Data model proposal
### ResourceProgram vs Location
Many programs should have multiple location entries.
- Organization (existing)
- Resource (existing) → treat as Program-level description
- Add/extend a Location/ServiceArea model for program instances:
  - address, city, state, zip (public org info; not user PII)
  - counties_served / service_area geometry
  - intake_phone, intake_url, hours
  - eligibility rules (structured fields)

### Eligibility fields (structured)
- age_min: int | null
- household_size_min/max: int | null
- income_limit_type: enum (AMI %, absolute monthly, absolute annual, unknown)
- income_limit_value: number | null
- housing_status_required: enum set
- active_duty_required: bool | null
- discharge_required: enum | null
- veteran_status_required: bool (default true for vet-focused resources)
- docs_required: string[] (free text items)
- waitlist_status: enum (open/closed/unknown)

### Verification
- last_verified_at
- verified_by: enum (official_directory, provider_contact, user_report, automated_link_check)
- verification_notes

## Data sourcing (DC/MD/VA first)
- Identify official SSVF provider directory source(s) and map providers to locations + counties served
- Seed a small set of providers for DC/MD/VA with verified intake details

## API / Search changes
- Extend search endpoint to accept eligibility filters
- Add server-side matching logic that returns "match reasons" for transparency
- Ensure filters are optional and degrade gracefully

## UI components
- EligibilityWizard component
- MatchReasonChips component
- ResourceDetail: add per-location "Intake" section + verification info

## Rollout plan
1) Add schema fields for per-location eligibility + verification
2) Add wizard UI (client-only persistence)
3) Add matching logic + match reasons
4) Seed DC/MD/VA SSVF providers as initial dataset
5) Expand to food distributions/events and benefits consults

  - UX for results and reporting updates
  - Initial DC/MD/VA housing-focused rollout plan
- Spec explicitly states no PII storage and avoids account creation

title: Fix header shift when dropdowns open on landing page
description:
## Problem
When opening category/state dropdowns on the landing page search bar, the header shifts left while the page content stays in place (or vice versa).

## Root Cause
Radix UI Select component uses `react-remove-scroll` which adds `padding-right` to the body to compensate for hiding the scrollbar. The fixed header (`position: fixed; right: 0`) doesn't receive this padding, causing misalignment.

## Attempted Solutions

### 1. CSS scrollbar-gutter: stable
Added to html element - caused extra white space column on right side.

### 2. CSS !important overrides on body
```css
body {
  padding-right: 0 !important;
  margin-right: 0 !important;
}
```
Didn't work - Radix uses inline styles which have higher specificity.

### 3. overflow-y: scroll on html
Forces scrollbar to always show - caused extra white space.

### 4. MutationObserver to reset body styles (ScrollLockFix component)
Created `frontend/src/components/scroll-lock-fix.tsx` that observes body style changes and resets padding/margin. This worked but when combined with removing the CSS hacks, the shift returned.

## Current State
- ScrollLockFix component exists but header still shifts
- Need to either:
  1. Keep some CSS hacks alongside the MutationObserver
  2. Find a way to make the fixed header also respond to body padding
  3. Disable Radix scroll lock entirely at component level
  4. Use a different dropdown component that doesn't lock scroll

## Files Involved
- `frontend/src/components/scroll-lock-fix.tsx` - MutationObserver component
- `frontend/src/components/search-bar.tsx` - Landing page search with Select dropdowns
- `frontend/src/components/ui/select.tsx` - shadcn Select wrapper
- `frontend/src/app/globals.css` - CSS overrides
- `frontend/src/components/header.tsx` - Fixed header component

## Reference
User mentioned "react portal for dropdowns" as a past solution - worth investigating if Radix Portal config can help.
notes: Implemented scrollbar-compensation for fixed header by applying `padding-right: var(--removed-body-scroll-bar-size, 0px)` so Radix/RemoveScroll body scrollbar-gap no longer misaligns header. Also set `html` background to `--background` to avoid white gutter during scroll lock, and removed the MutationObserver-based `ScrollLockFix` hack from `frontend/src/app/layout.tsx`.
close_reason: Header no longer shifts when Radix Select dropdowns open; scrollbar-gap styling no longer shows white gutter; verified via Next build (needs network for font fetch).
